questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient of asian ethnicity with a BMI of 34 kg/m² has decided to seek surgical options to reduce her weight. She has multiple comorbidities. Which of the following would make her unsuitable for bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Severe depression would make her unsuitable for bariatric surgery. The patient should be psychologically stable before undergoing bariatric surgery.

Psychological instability makes the patient incapable of understanding the implications of the procedure. It becomes difficult for the patient to understand the lifestyle changes necessary for optimal outcomes. 

The indications for bariatric surgery as per international standards as well as the modifications specific for Asian and Indian populations are as follows:

International criteria Asian-specific modification in BMI
1. BMI ≥ 40 kg/m2 regardless of obesity-related comorbidities BMI ≥ 37.5 kg/m2

2. BMI ≥ 35 kg/m2 with obesity-related comorbidities, such as

  • Hypertension
  • Type 2 DM
  • Coronary artery disease (CAD)
  • Dyslipidemia
  • Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA): Pickwickian syndrome
  • Arthritis and functional impairment
 BMI ≥ 32.5 kg/m2

3. Has failed to lose weight despite:

  • Lifestyle modifications
  • Pharmacotherapy
  • Psychotherapy
  
4. Is psychologically stable  
5. Motivated and capable of understanding lifestyle changes  

 The criteria for Asian and Indian patients has been modified by reducing the BMI by 2.5 points. This modification takes into account the geographical differences in food, lifestyle, and genetic make-up of patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for bariatric surgery?

choices.text: Failure to lose weight despite psychotherapy

questions.solution:
Failure to lose weight by an obese patient despite psychotherapy, pharmacotherapy, and lifestyle modifications is an indication for metabolic surgery.

Potential contraindications to metabolic and bariatric surgery include:

  • Severe medical disease making anesthesia or surgery prohibitively risky (American Society of Anesthesiologists class IV)
  • Mentally incompetent to understand the procedure
  • Inability or unwillingness to change lifestyle postoperatively
  • Drug, alcohol, or other addiction (including smoking)
  • Active problem of bulimia or other eating disorder
  • Psychological instability (schizophrenia, severe depression)      
  • Unsupportive home environment

questions.text: For a patient being considered for bariatric surgery, which of the following will you not include when calculating the Obesity Surgery-Mortality risk score (OS-MRS score)?
questions.solution:
Type-2 Diabetes mellitus (DM) is not a component of the Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS).

Edmonton Obesity Staging System (EOSS) and Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS) are used to discuss with patients the likely prognosis without surgery, and the risk of complications.

Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS):

Risk factor Score
Age ≥ 45 yr 1
BMI ≥ 50 1
Male gender 1
Hypertension 1
DVT(Deep Vein Thrombosis)/ PE(Pulmonary Embolism) 1
Risk Category Score Post-op mortality
A (Low) 0-1 0.3
B (Moderate) 2-3 1.7
C (High) 4-5 3.2

Note: Uncontrolled diabetes is considered a risk factor, as in any other surgery. However, it is not considered under the OS-MRS scoring system.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with a BMI of 42 kg/m² with central obesity is scheduled to undergo bariatric surgery. As preparation for surgery, he is advised to follow a low-carbohydrate, low-fat, and moderate-protein meal, for two weeks. On follow-up, he is found to be non-compliant with the diet. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Psychological re-evaluation is necessary to address the underlying psychological blocks in a patient who is unable to comply with the diet.

Morbidly obese individuals, especially those with central obesity, have large livers that make surgery impossible. Liver shrinkage diet helps reduce the size of the liver. This allows mobility for the surgeon and increases the chances of a safer procedure.  

Liver shrinkage diet:

  • Low-carbohydrate, low-fat and moderate protein diet
  • Started at least 2 weeks prior to the surgery

The ability to comply with the diet and lose weight suggests that the patient is willing to make an effort to adopt lifestyle modifications. Failure to do so must arouse suspicion of important underlying psychological blocks, which need addressing.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Pyloric exclusion with gastrojejunostomy is not a bariatric surgery. It is a technique used in the repair of duodenal and pancreatic injuries.

Based on their mechanism of action, bariatric surgeries are categorized as follows:

Mechanism of action Common procedures
Purely Restrictive
  • Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding
  • Sleeve gastrectomy
  • Intragastric balloon placement
Predominantly Malabsorptive
  • Biliopancreatic diversion (BPD)
  • Duodenal switch (DS)
Restrictive + Malabsorptive
  • Roux-en-Y gastrojejunostomy (gastric bypass)

Purely malabsorptive procedures, Biliopancreatic diversion (BPD) and Duodenal switch (DS), cause maximum weight loss and maximum improvement in metabolic co-morbidities of obesity.

questions.text: Which of the following is a reversible bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Laparoscopic gastric banding and intra-gastric balloon placement surgeries are considered to be reversible bariatric surgeries.

It is because the gastric band or the intragastric balloon can be removed once the desired weight loss or metabolic benefit is achieved.

An inflatable band is placed just below the GE junction 
↓
A small virtual stomach pouch is created 
↓
Reduces hunger (probably vagally mediated)
↓ 
Reduced consumption of food
↓ 
Weight loss

Complications of LAGB include:

  • Prolapse / Slippage (most common)
  • Band erosion of the stomach wall and rupture
  • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (highest risk within 1 month of surgery), managed with early ambulation, pressure stockings and LMWH.

questions.text: In recent years, what is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Sleeve gastrectomy is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery, in recent years.

A vertical sleeve is created, resecting most of the greater curvature
↓ 
Restriction of stomach capacity
↓ 
Early satiety
↓ 
Reduced consumption of food
↓ 
Weight loss

Advantages of sleeve gastrectomy:

  • Less challenging procedure
  • Preservation of pylorus (avoids gastric dumping)
  • No need for serial adjustments (as seen with gastric banding)
  • Reduction in internal hernias (as seen with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass)  

Complications of sleeve gastrectomy:

  • Bleed from the staple line
  • Leakage from staple line (close to the angle of His)

Recent update:

Sleeve gastrectomy has become the most common primary procedure for bariatric surgery.

Refer: https://www.ifso.com/pdf/4th-ifso-global-registry-report-last-2018.pdf

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with diabetes and a BMI of 46 kg/m² underwent laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG). On the second postoperative day, she developed fever, tachycardia, and blood reports show leucocytosis. What is the next best step in her management?

choices.text: Send blood for culture and sensitivity
USG abdomen to locate the septic focus

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, tachycardia, and leucocytosis in a postoperative patient of LSG should raise suspicion for leak along the gastric staple line. The next best step in the management of this patient is to perform a contrast-enhanced CT.

Leaks following LSG most commonly occur in the proximal third of the stomach, close to the angle of His. Early leaks are due to tissue trauma and staple misfire, and late leaks are usually due to ischemia and high intragastric pressure.

Management of the leak involves providing nutritional support to the patient and adequate drainage. Once the leak is diagnosed, the patient should be kept nil per oral.

Total parenteral nutrition and antibiotic therapy should be started in the patient. Drainage can be done either by CT-guided percutaneous catheter placement, endoscopic stenting, or operative procedures.

Note: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a risk factor for an anastomotic leak. Treatment with continuous positive airway pressure might reduce this risk.

Since the leaks following LSG are often difficult to treat, they are called the Achilles heel of the operation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Roux-en-Y gastric bypass in bariatric surgery?

choices.text: Gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature.
Biliary limb is 100-150 cm in length
It is a purely restrictive type of procedure.

questions.solution:
Gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature in Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

A small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature
↓ 
Create a shorter biliary limb of 30 - 50 cm (duodenum);
Create a longer Roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum)
↓ 
Bowel continuity is restored by a Y - jejunojejunostomy 
↓ 
Restrictive + Malabsorptive mechanism
↓ 
Weight loss

Note:

Biliary limb is usually kept short (30-50 cm) in order to reduce vitamin and mineral deficiencies.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presented to the casualty with vomiting and severe colicky pain in the abdomen for the past 48 hours. She had undergone a weight reduction surgery six months ago and had achieved around 30% weight loss. Her plain X-ray abdomen is given below. Which of the following bariatric procedures was most likely done in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiograph (dilated bowel segments with valvulae conniventes in the left upper quadrant) are suggestive of small bowel obstruction. Bariatric surgery, specifically, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery is associated with the creation of mesenteric defects. The small bowel can herniate through these defects (internal hernia) and get strangulated, resulting in bowel obstruction. 

In addition, as the person loses weight (due to the bariatric procedure), the protective, space-occupying effect of the mesenteric fat is lost and hernia spaces open up, further increasing the risk of internal hernia. The laparoscopic procedure has a higher risk compared to open surgery since fewer adhesions form to tether small-bowel loops and prevent them from herniating. 

Adequate closure of the mesenteric defects by the surgeon at the time of operation significantly reduces the risk of internal hernia.

Other complications specific to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass:

  • Nutritional deficiencies: iron (most common), folate, Vitamin A, D, K and B12      
  • Anastomosis site leak      
  • Bleeding from the site of gastrojejunostomy   
  • Dumping syndrome
  • Marginal ulcers
  • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism

Option A: Sleeve gastrectomy is often complicated by staple line leak.

Option B: Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding is associated with band slippage and erosion.

Option D: Endoluminal stapling is also used to create a gastric sleeve. It is associated with postoperative nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and transient dysphagia.

questions.text: A patient who previously underwent biliopancreatic diversion surgery has been having excessive malabsorption and is now being planned for a revisional procedure to increase the length of the common channel. What is the usual length of the common channel?
questions.solution:
The usual length of the common channel in biliopancreatic diversion (BPD) is 50 cm (0.5 m).  Revisions increase common channel by up to 150 cm. 

The length of the common channel plays a significant role in the amount of weight loss achieved with BPD procedure. A shorter common channel implies a greater length of the bypassed small bowel. This induces more malabsorption and thereby greater weight loss. 

Distal hemigastrectomy is performed to create a residual gastric pouch
↓
Terminal ileum is divided 250 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve
↓
Gastroileostomy: Proximal anastomosis between the distal end of divided ileum and residual gastric pouch
↓
Ileoileostomy: Distal anastomosis between the proximal end of divided ileum and terminal ileum
↓
A common channel of 50 cm is established
↓
Malabsorption
↓
Weight loss

 

Prophylactic cholecystectomy is usually performed since there is an increased incidence of gallstones due to malabsorption of bile salts.

Complications of biliopancreatic diversion surgery:

  • Anastomosis site leak
  • Nutritional deficiencies: Iron; folate; vitamins A, D, K, and B12
  • Marginal ulcers 
  • Bleeding
  • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (maximum risk within 1 month of surgery), managed with early ambulation, pressure stocking, and LMWH

Biliopancreatic diversion surgery is an older technique of bariatric surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a surgical step that will be done during a duodenal switch procedure?
questions.solution:
In duodenal switch (DS) surgery, gastroduodenostomy is not performed.

Sleeve gastrectomy is performed 
↓ 
Duodenum is divided 2 cm beyond the pylorus;
Terminal ileum is divided 250 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve 
↓ 
Duodenoileostomy: Proximal anastomosis between the distal end of divided ileum and duodenum 
↓ 
Ileoileostomy: Distal anastomosis between the proximal end of divided ileum and terminal ileum 
↓ 
A common channel of 100 cm is established 
↓ 
Malabsorption 
↓ 
Weight loss 

Prophylactic cholecystectomy is usually performed since there is an increased incidence of gallstones due to malabsorption of bile salts.                                        

Complications of duodenal switch surgery:

  • Anastomosis site leak and bleeding
  • Nutritional deficiencies - Iron, folate, Vitamin A, D, K and B12
  • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (maximum risk within 1 month of surgery) - managed with early ambulation, pressure stocking, and LMWH In comparison to BPD, the incidence of marginal ulcers is negligible

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in patients who undergo bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary embolism is the most common cause of death in patients of bariatric surgery.

Pathogenesis:

Obesity
 ↓ 
Increased levels of plasminogen activator inhibitor-1
 ↓ 
Blocks conversion of plasminogen to plasmin
 ↓ 
Decreased fibrinolytic activity
 ↓ 
Hypercoagulable state
 ↓ 
Increased risk for VTE

Morbidly obese patients are physically inactive. Restricted mobility post-surgery potentiates this risk of developing deep vein thrombosis. 

Note: Most common cause of death in bariatric surgery is DVT/pulmonary embolism. Most common complication of bariatric surgery is an anastomotic leak

questions.text: In patients who undergo gastric bypass surgery (bariatric surgery), what is the 3-year percentage of diabetes remission?
questions.solution:
The 3-year percentage of diabetes remission for gastric bypass surgery is 50%. 

Different Bariatric surgeries and their Outcomes :

  Protein/Calorie Malabsorption 3 year % Excess Weight Loss (EWL) 3 yr % Diabetes remission
Gastric band No

40 -50 %

 20 %
Gastric bypass No 50 - 60 % 50 %
Sleeve gastrectomy No 50 - 60 % 50 %
Biliopancreatic diversion / Duodenal switch  Yes 70 -80 % 80 %

 

Purely malabsorptive procedures, Biliopancreatic division (BPD) and Duodenal switch (DS), cause maximum weight loss and maximum improvement in metabolic co-morbidities of obesity.
